discussion.content: was in exam June15,2023

Configure multi-factor authentication for cloud services → Microsoft 365 only
Configure email disclaimers → Both Microsoft 365 and on-premises
Configure compliance → Both Microsoft 365 and on-premises
Set frequency of Microsoft Office 365 updates → Microsoft 365 only

MFA is M365 management only, exchange server doesnt natively support it. It needs to be federated or connected to a third party - https://infrasos.com/implementing-mfa-in-microsoft-exchange-server/

Disclaimers is both - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/policy-and-compliance/mail-flow-rules/signatures?view=exchserver-2019

Compliance is technically both, exchange server does have compliance features, but managing it in a hybrid environment would require M365 management through the compliance portal to unlock all its features like eDiscovery - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/policy-and-compliance/policy-and-compliance?view=exchserver-2019

Frequency of updates is both, https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/updates/overview-update-channels#configure-the-update-channel

For Office 365 Updates in a hybrid environment
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/deployoffice/updates/choose-how-to-deliver-updates#update-solutions-for-hybrid-update-sources

The choices are there, each have advtanges and disadvantages:

Step 1: Choose your update source: Cloud, on-premises location, or hybrid
The first step in deciding how the Microsoft 365 Apps should be updated, is to choose where updates should be delivered from: From the cloud, from on-premises locations or a mix of both (also known as "hybrid"). The following section lays out these sources and calls out the individual benefits and challenges. The second step is to review and choose a fitting solution for managing updates for the chosen update source.
